title: A font called "Stem"
content:
Today I needed to open a 4 year old photoshop document, and got the "font substitution is about to occur" message.   
   
OK, so the font was missing. I have gone through the required process of various search engines and type foundries, without any luck.   
   
Photoshop insists that the font is called "stem", but so far I have not been able to find a single font with this name, perhaps it has mistaken the name?   
   
Anyway here is a sample image:   
   
 ![echtzeit means realtime in german](http://web.archive.org/web/20081205014300im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/40774.gif)

 [‹ (x) Henry Cotton's - Belwe {James}](http://web.archive.org/web/20081205014300/http:/typophile.com/node/5649 "Go to previous forum topic") [(x) Demand Response - Century Gothic {Eduardo} ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20081205014300/http:/typophile.com/node/5642 "Go to next forum topic")
author: danoise

comments.content:
Hey are those serifs on the "T" and the top-right one on the "I" rounded or am I seeing things? Oh yeah and the top-left corner of the "H" seems rounded to me too.   
I hope other people can see this as well... or else this is a definite proof that I need sleep.   
   
Sorry no font ID yet.   
   
hilsen   
magnus

Hej Magnus,   
   
I think this is due to the fact that the image was from an old version of Photoshop (which had terrible font-previews in small resolutions).   
I am sorry that the resolution is so low, but there's not really anything I can do about it   
   
The corners are actually angular (45
